awd_titl_txt: University of Virginia Robert Noyce Scholarship Program
awd_abstract_narration: Developing more highly qualified science teachers to serve in high needs schools is a national challenge. The University of Virginia in partnership with Hampton, Alexandria, and Culpeper School Districts will implement Phase 1 of the Robert Noyce Scholarship and Stipend Program which will recruit, educate and retain academically talented science and engineering undergraduates and STEM professionals who will become certified high school science teachers in the partner school districts and other high-need schools in Virginia. The educational experience for Noyce Scholarship and Stipend recipients will include preparing them to become effective science teachers, and Teacher-Leaders in engineering design integration in K-12 science instruction. Robert Noyce Scholarship and Stipend recipients will be supported through a number of proven strategies, including mentoring, targeted advising, and induction support. Data will be collected to provide insights into the integration of engineering design in pre-service science teacher education courses, which may lead to programmatic changes in teacher education program. The project will be rigorously evaluated to determine the effectiveness of the recruitment and retention strategies and to determine the impact of the program on Robert Noyce Scholarship and Stipend recipients' content knowledge, instructional practices, and skills for integrating engineering design in science instruction. Overall, this project will contribute to the number of certified secondary science teachers in high-need schools in Virginia, and stands to increase student achievement in science.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

por.por_cntn:
University of Virginia in partnership with Hampton, Alexandria, and Culpeper School Districts has completed the Phase 1 of Robert Noyce Scholarship and Stipend Program that was designed to recruit and train 50 science and engineering undergraduates and STEM professionals to become certified middle and high school science teachers. In the five-year funding period, the project recruited and trained 59 Noyce scholars (35 Biology, 9 Earth Science, 8 Physics, and 7 Chemistry). These scholars are teaching in high-need school districts in Virginia and other states. The educational experience for Noyce Scholarship and Stipend recipients included training in effective science teaching strategies for inclusive classrooms, developing inquiry lessons, developing engineering design integrated science (EDIS) instructional materials, and how to teach EDIS lessons in  middle and high school classrooms. Noyce scholars were also trained as Teacher-Leaders in engineering design integration in K-12 science instruction, and Teacher grant writing. Noyce scholars were supported through several proven strategies, including mentoring, targeted advising, field experiences, and induction support.  The evaluation results show that Noyce scholars increased their understanding of engineering design, developed positive perceptions of teaching science through engineering design process, developed sound instructional planning skills, and teaching skills for engineering design integrated science lessons. The results also show that  EDIS lessons  Noyce scholars taught in schools increased student understanding of science content knowledge, engineering design process, and their perceptions of engineering design. This project has positively impacted the University of Virginia science teacher education program, and participant school districts. For example, the enrollment of students in science teacher education increased, and the recruitment and instructional materials for the Noyce project have become essential for the science teacher education program. Several Noyce scholars are teaching in participant school districts. Project outcomes have been disseminated to STEM community through research publications in peer-reviewed journals, and presentations at research and teacher conferences. Noyce scholars were involved in disseminating project outcomes  through presentations  at Virginia Association for Science Teachers conference.  Overall, this project achieved its goal and objectives. The project has contributed to the number of certified middle and high school science teachers in high-need schools in Virginia, and other states.
